div.head: Tri-County Historical Itinerary
div.byline: ELMORE BARCE of Fowler and J. W. WHICKCAR of Attica Acting as Guides1
div.p: STOP No. 1

We are now one mile east of the northeast corner of the present corporation of the city of Attica. There was located here a sawmill which sawed nothing but pine timber, and from this dam the water was afterwards taken to Attica to run the old woolen mill, grist mill, tanning yard, and this dam practically made the town of Attica. This stream and location are called Stone Cut, you could spend a day here looking over the scenery, but here at the dam is the historical spot. One of the first sawmills, probably the first in Fountain county run by water power, stood here. This is the old mill race. They took the water across the stream in a wooden flume and turned it into the mill or water wheel. The saw was an up and down saw, a muley, and sawed nothing but pine timber. Some of the logs which were sawed into lumber here were brought from north of Independence. This sawmill was run by a man named William Brown. He is buried at Bethel, and was a Methodist preacher. On his tombstone is carved "Rev. William Brown". This mill started in 1829 or 30 and run until 1845, when Dan Yount and John Yount, two brothers, bought the mill site and dam, built a race and continued this water on down to Attica, two and one-half miles, it is only one mile direct to Attica. The first thing that was operated by this water power was a distillery, Standards Distillery, then Grant's Tanning Yard, and next the sawmill, then the grist mill, and last the old woolen mills, belonging to the Younts. It was bringing this water power to Attica that made all the industries, that brought Mayesville and Robroy to Attica.

After this land had been used for a sawmill the Wabash Railroad company bought the entire tract of land, 40 acres,
1 This is a stenographic report of a trip taken on the 3d Sunday of June, 1924. The two papers following enlarge on the local history here reviewed.
and operated a stone quarry here for years. All of the old bridges along the Wabash railroad are built of sand stone taken from here. About 125 men worked in the stone quarry just below the dam. This creek is now called Stone Cut. In the early days the stone bluffs came so close together along the top that the boys jumped back and forth from one bank to the other. The Wabash took all of that stone out. There was a hotel down this stream near the railroad that accommodated about one hundred people, the men that worked at the stone quarry.

This spot is the beginning of Attica, its birthplace. But now the city of Attica doesn't know of this place. Here is where most of the pine timber grew. The balance came down the river. They hauled the timber in over this ridge with ox teams, and a chute was arranged here and the logs shot down into the mill pond, and floated there until they were ready for them. The mill ran all the time, winter and summer. After the lumber was sawed it was hauled up the river to Fulton . Not a nail was used in making these flat boats. They were made with wooden pins. When the boats were finished, the men went out in the timber and got two large poles, which were fixed on each side of the boat. On the back of the poles they laid a floor, over which they stretched a tent, under which they lived, and where they kept the hay for the animals which they took with them on the boat. When they got to New Orleans they sold the flat boats to the ship yards, and these poles were sold for masts. Everything they handled was at a profit. The Flint Bar was the only place in the country where flat boats were being made extensively at that time. The man who ran the sawmill was Brown. The man who made the boats was Fulton , and the man who oversaw the shipping of goods, was Jesse Marvin. He went on practically all the trips to New Orleans . Perhaps some of the people here today remember Jesse Marvin. I saw him practically every week, and it was Jesse Marvin who told me of the mill. I have been there and to Flint with him, and I am telling the story as it was told to me by Marvin.

The first Swedes brought into the state of Indiana, were brought by the Wabash R. R. to work in the stone quarry.
One hundred and twenty-five of them bought the land up and down this creek and there were at least fifty Swedish families who built cabins here. Leifs, Burkes, Johnsons, Lyons, Run-grains, Humstedts, Munsons, Swansons, and many other families were raised here. Practically all the Swedish families in Attica and a lot of these over in Warren and Benton counties came from here and many Swedish families went from here to Paxton, Illinois . It was called Sweden, and when I went to school there would be as many as eighty Swedish children in the little school house. I knew one Swede, twenty-two years of age, who came here and learned his English letters, afterwards became very prominent in educational work in Colorado .
STOP No. 2

On the road to Riverside, two and one-half miles northeast of the corporation of Attica. Over to the south here, across the railroad, was the old James Killin stone quarry. All the old tombstones that you see in the old graveyards in these counties, practically all of them, were made there. There were thirty-five men making these tombstones, and stones for foundations, etc. The first nursery in Fountain county was in the west end of this field, and all the splendid old orchards that your fathers tell you about, all of those trees came from that nursery. It was operated by a man by the name of Jonathan Swain. His wife was a sister of Dan Yount's.
When Jonathan Swain got his money out of this nursery he went to Iowa and bought four sections of land.

There is a little stone spring house just the other side of James Anderson's residence, built by Jonathan Swain ninety years ago, out of stone taken from this quarry, which is still in a good state of preservation.

Straight across the road and railroad lived a family by the name of Slusser, and when Judge John R. Porter started from Williamsport to make his circuit, he stopped here at the Slusser house to take dinner. Just beyond where the house stood is a graveyard where five hundred early settlers are buried, who mostly died of the milk sickness. Abraham Lincoln's mother died of the same illness.

Just a little southeast of here is where Adam Rhodes and
son, Pearce Rhodes, made all the furniture for the early settlers, by water power. They used mostly blue ash timber because it split straight.

The rarest tree is not the sassafrass tree in Ravine park in Attica, but it is the blue ash which you will see just as you enter the park, going up the hollow, which was very valuable, and there are only a few of them left in the state.
STOP No. 3

Right in front of the Baptist church at Independence, looking toward the river. On the ridge is where the first log house was built north of the Vermillion river, probably we better say the first fort north of Terre Haute . The stone you see was in the foundation. The logs were numbered. They were brought up the river from Vincennes . The fort was built by Zachariah Cicot. When he built the stockade he included a spring of water. Cicot landing is up the river about half a mile. The Pottawattomie trail came through here and then went on to Thorntown and Strawtown. This same Pottawattomie trail went to Oxford . It started at Greensville, Dark county , Ohio , and crossed the Wabash at Independence, an east and west trail. We are now in the old town of Independence. The town wasn't laid off till 1832. The fort was established in the spring of 1817. There were so many Indians here that when the first white settlers came they could not settle on this side of the Wabash .

There was 640 acres in the Cicott reservation here. It was given to Perig. He was a Pottawattomie chief, and the father-in-law of Cicott. Perig gave the land to John Baptist Cicott and John B. sold the claim to his father, Zachariah Cicott. When Zachariah Cicott was about ten years of age he went down to Vincennes . There he received a good education. We are going to the spot where Cicott was born. He was born October 19, 1781, the same day that Cornwallis surrendered to Washington. Cicott lived all his life here and died within 100 feet of where he was born. There is a lake in Cass county named for Zachariah Cicott and a street in Logansport . It was indeed a fortunate thing for William Henry Harrison that he had a man like Cicott, thirty years
of age, who knew this country. It was Cicott who piloted his army through this country.

Cicott began raising horses here in the year 1800 and by 1811 he had mounted all of the Pottawattomie and the Kickapoos. The Kickapoo country came up along the river, to the water shed of the Kickapoo creek and from there north was the Pottawattomie country. No Pottawattomies lived across the river from Attica. This was Kickapoo country and the Kickapoos lived there. The old chief, Pisqua, who is buried at Kickapoo is not a Kickapoo, but a Pottawattomie. The battle that was fought by Hardin is down the river below here and on this side of the river, on the Warren county side. Here is where they killed the six warriors and captured the fifty-two prisoners. That was in 1791, on the first day of June. We will see the place later. The battle took place on the right hand side of this river road, just as you go up the hill after you cross the C. E. I. railroad at Kickapoo crossway.
STOP No. 4
We are now at Zachariah Cicott's grave in the old cemetery at Independence.
We spoke to you about the old stones in the cemetery, this is one of them. All of these old grave stones are from that old quarry that I showed you across the Wabash .
I have a little personal pride in the lettering on these grave stones because it was done by my father's oldest brother, Luke Whickcar.
This is the grave of Zachariah Cicott, and here is the grave of his wife. She was a full-blooded Pottawattomie Indian, the daughter of Perig. She died in 1838 at the age of 38 years.
The inscription of Cicott's wife's tombstone is: "In Memory of Elizabeth, Consort of Zachariah Cicott, who died Nov. 18, 1838, aged 38 yrs."
Zachariah Cicott died in 1850, at the age of 69 years. This woman he married was from Flint river, Michigan .

This is the grave of the father of Dan Mace, and here is the grave of his mother. Dan Mace represented this district in congress for many years. He was the democratic candidate
in 1851, and his opponent was David Brier, who lived at Robroy. Mace lived at Independence and practiced law here. After Dan Mace was elected to congress he moved to LaFayette , and was later postmaster there. While he lived in LaFayette he practiced law, and was attorney for Ed Sumner of Benton county , in a long lawsuit which went to the supreme court. This litigation that Ed Sumner had was with the Pottawattomie heirs of Toppenebee and Dan Mace was Sumner's attorney. He won the case.

This is the Pottawattomie trail that we came out, running north from Independence to Pine Village. It was at one time planked and was called the Plank road. Job Cassel collected the toll at Independence. He was the father of Job Cassel who was at one time recorder of Benton county , and James Cassel of West Point.

After the destruction of old Fort Ouiatenon in August, 1791, when Wilkinson destroyed the fort, which was never rebuilt, Cicott came here and began raising horses and trading in furs in 1800. All the furs of the northwest country, up to Lake Michigan and on north, were brought down here, down this trail and traded to Cicott, traded for whiskey, horses and merchandise. Cicott then took the furs down the river to New Orleans .

quote.p: This Pottawattomie trail runs in an easterly direction from Independence to Thorntown and Strawtown, and west and north to Chicago . It branched at Parish Grove in Benton county , one branch going to Buncom, Momence, Blue Island and on to Fort Dearborn . When this trail gets to Oxford it intersects a trail which goes on from that country to Fort Ouiatenon. This passes through what we call the Beaver Lake country, and that is where the Pottawattomie Indians secured much of the beaver, otter, mink and other furs which they brought down here and traded. Also on this trail when you come to Morocco, just north of Morocco, you come to Beaver creek. This is the first large creek north of Morocco. It is an outlet of Beaver Lake, which at one time covered several sections of land and that was a famous trading region, and practically all the furs which were shipped south came from the Beaver Lake country in Indiana and north.

div.p:
Now as we go back if you will look to the right where we come to Independence you will see two springs. Cicott died in the house just to the left as you cross the first street. He
was born within one hundred feet of where he died. He died in 1850. We will stop there and show you the house and the springs.

Newlin H. Yount lived here in 1850. Most of the time he lived in the neighborhood across the Wabash . He probably did more to preserve the history of this locality than any other man. He wrote articles at different times which the papers of Attica printed, and he told these incidents in a much better way than we are able to tell them. His articles can be found in the old files of the Attica Ledger at the Attica library.
STOP NO. 5

This spring, Big Spring at Independence, should be called the Pottawattomie spring. The spring used to come from under the large oak tree, but finally changed to this spot. This spring formerly operated a grist mill just below here, and furnished plenty of water, year around, for the mill, until the mill burned. I have taken many a grist to that mill.
STOP NO. 6. MAYESVILLE
Here is the site of the old town of Mayesville and the Range line, range 7, on this side and 6 on the other side. We are about 18 rods west of the range line.

When this land was laid off it was laid off three miles on each side of the range line, two miles in Logan township. It is just one miles from here to Riverside, and the township line. The government laid off this land in 1823. This point is directly south of Gilboa church and Gilboa cemetery in Gilboa township, Benton county , Indiana, and directly north of Newtown, Mellott, and Wallace in Fountain county .

The Pottawattomie trail came down and through the level country on this side of the creek, and across the river was the Cicott landing and fort. There were so many Indians around this post when the early settlers came here in 1824 to enter the land, they couldn't stay at Cicott's. They came over here and built a public hotel. The lumber for the hotel was sawed at Vincennes , and like Cicott's cabin, was rafted up the river. That hotel was built in the spring of 1824. There were twenty-two rooms upstairs and downstairs a big dining room and
a kitchen and a big front room all with fireplaces and then a room where they had groceries and things of that kind. Nobody paid anything to stay in the hotel but everyone had to furnish flour or meal or cut wood for the fireplaces.

These early settlers went up and down the river for three miles and took up the land on north into Benton county and south into Fountain county , a distance of 25 miles, all the land was taken up by people who were related. This was the center of their operations. They came here and selected their land on the prairie. This country here for six miles wide and 50 miles long was settled from this point. The two men most active in the early settlement of this territory were George Worthington, my great grandfather, and Thomas Hemphill. Thomas Hemphill had five boys, Andrew, Thomas, Edward, James and John. The old man began operating a grist mill, the first grist mill in northern Fountain county . This mill operated from 1825 till 1860 when the War broke out. At one time there were probably 800 people living here in the town of Mayesville.

When the flatboat industry went out and the canal came in, and water was taken to Attica, all the people of Mayesville went to Attica. John and James Hemphill built the Rivere House in Attica with money made here in Mayesville. Mr. Duncan, who ran a general store here built the store room in Attica where Crigler's drug store is now located, and the store room this side of it, with money made here, and so on with many other industries of Attica. The money to start them was made here in Mayesville. When the Hemphills left, the whole town left. That was in 1846 when the canal reached Attica. The grist mill was south and west beyond the railroad about a quarter of a mile from here. This was the business district of the town here and most of the houses were over in the field across the railroad. We are six miles northeast from Attica.
The Wabash and Erie canal destroyed the town of Mayesville. Here is where Jesse Marvin had his cooper shop and made barrels. Here they loaded wood, lumber and whiskey.

On account of the condition of the bottom lands we cannot get to the Flint Bar. That is where the flat boats were
made. Flint is right on the river, about three miles south of here.
Mr. Goodwine: You didn't tell us how this hotel was maintained. You said it didn't cost anything to stay there.

Mr. Whickcar: It was maintained by donations. These people came from Mayesville, Kentucky . They brought flour and meal, and the men fished and shot deer and brought the game, fowl, and fish in and the women cooked them.

You remember Curtis Newell. There was a window in the old Presbyterian church at Williamsport in his memory. His wife was one of the women who came here and helped cook. She was one of the most interesting women I ever knew. She was the grandmother of Mrs. Will Cronkhite of West Lebanon . She lived till about 1880. She is buried in the old cemetery at Williamsport .

George Worthington, who was a brother of Thomas Worthington, the first United States senator and third governor of the state of Ohio , and William Morrison, who was excongressman Morrison's grandfather, were among the early settlers here. Peter Weaver was the first settler in this locality who had no Indian blood in his veins. He came here to make his home. He was originally from Virginia , but came here from Wayne county , Indiana. He and his son, Patrick, came up the river in 1822. My uncle married Patrick Weaver's daughter. I spent my early childhood bothering him. They came up to Flint in 1822. Peter wanted land on the Wea Prairie but didn't know how to get it and Cicott solved the problem for him with the Burnetts. Mrs. Burnett was Kaukeama, a sister of Topenebee, the only sister so far as I know, but I think he had a half brother. Topenebee was the principal chieftain of the Pottawattomie tribe. He signed more treaties than any other Indian. He always signed first. He was not only the head of the Pottawattomie tribe as a state, but also at the head of their religion. They were the largest tribe of Indians in northern Indiana, much the largest. Unfortunately for Topenebee he acquired the drink habit, but one thing greatly to his credit, he was one of the Indians who saved a portion of the lives at the massacre of Fort Dearborn . There is a monument in Chicago , at the foot of eighteenth
street, erected by the Pullmans, on the site of the massacre of Fort Dearborn , where Wells was killed. Topenebee was there and stopped the massacre. He was the brother of Kaukeama, and she married William Burnett, and the Burnetts lived in Wabash township, Fountain county , Indiana, in what is now the barnyard of Fred Latourette. Burnett was a Frenchman, but he wasn't from the Ouiatenon settlement, he was from up on the lakes. The land laid off to his heirs was called Burnett's reservation. Burnett's creek, which flows by the battle ground in Tippecanoe county , was named for this famly.

Zechariah Cicott and Peter Weaver got Kaukeama and her children to locate six sections of land as a reservation, including the home of Peter Weaver. One section is in Fountain county and the other five sections in Tippecanoe county . It is known as Burnett's reservation on the Wea. After the Burnetts claimed this land, before the entry of lands at Craw-fordsville, Peter Weaver purchased of the Burnett's all of this tract of land, afterwards entering other lands from the government in Tippecanoe county . All the lands in this country were offered for entry at Crawfordsville on the 24th day of December, 1824. Fortunately we have a splendid description of this day in Old Settlers written by Sanford Cox in 1860. Among others that he names there is Peter Weaver, who had gone to Crawfordsville to enter land. We will go to the land that Cox's father took up from the government. Most of Cox's Old Settlers was written at the forks of Cold creek, which is Veedersburg. No one living there knows that one of the finest pieces of Indiana history was written near Veedersburg. Cox didn't like it there, so he moved up on the Wea Prairie , and finally died there. Sanford Cox went into the Civil war and was in the 72nd Ind. He was the historian of that regiment, and it was my good fortune to sit at the side of Sanford Cox and talk to him about the Civil war and the early history of this country, while riding on the Monon railroad to Battle Ground, and we spent the day together there. A son of Sanford Cox, within the last three weeks, has visited in LaFayette . No one can write a history of the state of Indiana correctly without quoting from Sanford Cox.

When the canal was built through Mayesville in 1846, the workmen were attacked with Asiatic cholera. The first few deaths were at Flint, probably eight or ten, then about one hundred died here, and they were buried in that mound up there in that little bunch of trees. There are a few markers up there. Then down by the river schoolhouse, two miles this side of Attica, on the river road, there is a big marl bed. There were at least five hundred Irishmen working on this canal. The first hundred that died were taken to Attica and buried in the old grave yard. I oversaw the rearrangement of the cemetery there and we unearthed a woman with the most perfect set of teeth I ever saw. I regret that I didn't keep them. She had died at that schoolhouse of the cholera. They died so fast they could not take care of them so they put the bodies in that marl bed and covered them with the marl and lime. There was one German lady, who took care of all these people at Flint till they died, then came over here and stayed at Mayesville till all these people died and then went down to the schoolhouse and took care of the people there until they died. She lived till June 16, 1911, in Davis township. I knew her well all my life. Her name was Ann Crouch, before she was married and she married a man by the name of Jahue Martin and still lived in Davis township.
STOP NO. 8. HIGH GAP

North of us are the Wea plains, over beyond the timber, this land requires no ditching. There is only one stream that has the impudence to try to cross that plain, and it goes only a short distance and is swallowed up. This is the territory that the Indians fought for, and we cannot blame them for fighting for a country like this. They raised more corn here than in any other place in the United States .

General Charles Scott reached here on June 1, 1791. When he reached this spot, after having traveled in a straight line from the mouth of the Kentucky river, he stopped for dinner about a mile and a half southeast of here, on the Shawnee river. They saw an Indian on horseback a few miles north of them. They made an effort to intercept him but the Indian had a very speedy horse and rode through the gap in the
timber, just to the west of where we are now standing. Scott advanced as rapidly as circumstances would permit and at one o'clock in the afternoon he had reached a point about two miles west of here, where he divided his army, on that range of hills over there to the west, at what is called Round Top. A portion of the army went down toward Flint Bar and on to Kickapoo, crossed the river at Kickapoo ford. A battle between this portion of the army and the Indians was fought on what is now called the Milligan farm, in which six Indians were killed and fifty-two captured. While this portion of the army was down there the rest of the army turned west and went to Ouiatenon. That was on the 1st day of June, 1791, when this army came from Kentucky to this splendid prairie. In August following, Wilkinson, who was second in command to Scott, led an army from Cincinnati and came down to Fort Ouiatenon and decided to destroy that town. He found on this side of the river 400 acres of corn in the roasting ear, and he and his men destroyed that corn with broadswords. After that the Indians left that spot and went on the other side of the river to the left of the little Vermillion river, near Cayuga, and camped there.

The following year, 1792, a man by the name of John Hamtramck, General Hamtramck, led an expedition of Indiana volunteers and militiamen from Vincennes and made an attack on the Indians and their villages on the north banks of the Big Vermillion river, near where that river empties into the Wabash . After the raid of Scott in the previous June, and Wilkinson in August, the Indians in this locality were very much weakened, on account of the destruction of their food, and many of them had died, but the remnants of these tribes were camping near the mouth of the Big Vermillion river. This was a favorite hunting ground for the reason that about a mile up the Vermillion river from the Wabash are rapids and the fish could be easily caught going up stream, as they could not get over the rapids, and the adjoining territory was filled with wild strawberries, blackberries, raspberries, plums, haws, and grapes, and was known far and near as the plum patch. This expedition of brave Hoosiers when it came near the Indian camp divided into two columns. One column
marched up the Vermillion river and crossed it and was to attack the Indians from the north, while the main army came directly up and across the Vermillion river and attacked them from the south. The warriors and braves were off on a hunting expedition, and there was no one there to molest but the worn out old men, the women, and children. Those were unmercifully slaughtered in the coldest of cold blood. There were so many of them killed that this portion of the army, on their return, are said to have boasted that they crossed the Vermillion river on the dead bodies of women, and children, and the water ran red with their blood.

The first white settlement in the state of Indiana was made at Ouiatenon. The army of Kentuckians crossed the Ohio river on the 23rd day of May, 1791, and consumed seven days in traversing what is now the state of Indiana, traveling on almost a straight line, and if you divide 155 miles, which is the distance between the mouth of the Kentucky river and this point, by seven, you will find the average mileage per day. They were on horseback, and carried ground corn and strips of venison for food.

Captain Bull, the Indian chief, came directly down through this gap in the timber with the Kentuckians following him. Some light can be thrown on why the Kentuckians followed the Indians up here. The Indians had stolen 15,000 horses from them and had killed 1500 Kentuckians, and when these white men came through this gap after those Indians they came with blood in their eyes.

This was all in timber at that time, except the gap. Colonel Harden, for whom Harden county , Kentucky , is named, was at the head of this army. The division of the army was made down west about two miles. Colonel Harden went to the left, and Captain Bull went east toward Ouiatenon. He notified the Indians in that direction but the Indians down the river were not notified. Harden and his army followed those Indians and as fast as they could they gathered in all the Indians on the east side of the river and crossed the river at Kickapoo ford, going toward Kickapoo, and the principal battle was fought in Warren county , on the Milligan farm.
STOP NO. 9. OUIATENON

The tents where the Indians lived and where they hunted and fished was in the Wabash bottom land, but Wilkinson's army stopped up here on the hill. The Wea Indians were on this side of the Wabash river. This was the Miami country. Mr. Barce is a Pottawattomie and you from West Lebanon are Kickapoos. The Pottowattomie and Kickapoos both came from the north and they kept encroaching on the Miami territory, driving the Miami south and east. If the Miami had given the same attention to the Pottowatomies and Kickapoos to drive them back, that they did to making raids down in Kentucky on white settlements, they could have held this territory. The Miami made one mistake, they were timber Indians, Indians who lived in the woods, and they refused to be mounted—they didn't take to the horse, while the Kickapoo and Pottawattomie were mounted. Cicott helped to mount them, and for that reason they were able to take over the Miami country. The Kickapoo and Potttawattomie were more hostile to the whites. Abel Godfrey told me that the Miami Indians did not take kindly to Tecumseh's confederacy. I heard him make a speech at Battle Ground, and that particular speech is one that you can get from Alva Reser very easily. The Kickapoo Indians are related to the Chippewa Indians of the north, and also to the Iroquois Indians. There is a question as to whether the Shawnee is an Indian at all because many of them had blue eyes and straight brown hair.

The first of the Great Lakes to be discovered by the white men was Lake Huron. When the white man first found Lake Huron, the Shawnee lived there. The next we hear of the Shawnees is down at Shawneetown in Illinois . He was the most cruel of all Indians. He went south from Illinois and the next we know of him is in Georgia and Florida . He is supposed to be a remnant of the old Norsemen that settled in the New England states, the new Vineland.
The farthest Pottawattomie town to the south was at the springs at Independence.

In the autumn of 1807 there was a meeting of all the Indians, beneath an oak tree, within the corporate limits of Attica. This splendid tree was cut in 1866, and was called the "Council Tree". The council held there was a council of Indians. Cicott was the only white man in that council, and he always lived with the Indians. The tree was in what is now Frank Merrick's yard. At that conference the Kickapoo, Pottawattomie, Miami, Delaware and Shawnee Indians all met, and the Shawnees were given a hunting territory in the Miami country, from the shed waters of the Shawnee creek to the south and reaching to the Wabash river on the north, and extending up the Tippecanoe river. The Shawnees came to this territory in June, 1808. The meeting was in the fall of 1807. The Shawnees made their headquarters at the mouth of the Tippecanoe , or at Prophetstown, and from there Tecumseh began his confederation of all the Indians. Cicott was valuable to Harrison for the reason that he lived all his life with the Indians, in fact he was an Indian. He could speak the language of all the tribes in this locality, he could speak both French and English. He had as much education as could be secured at old Fort Vincennes , and equipped with full knowledge of the Indians and with their confidence, he made a most valuable ally of Harrison's in the Indian country. He was considered among the Indian tribes as one of them. He had been to New Orleans , he had been all over Indiana, Illinois, Kentucky and Tennessee , and he had a remarkable amount of native ability.

Cicott did not like Tecumseh's brother, the Prophet. The Prophet pretended to read the hands, and claimed that he was invulnerable, could not be wounded, that he could turn the white man's bullets to snow or ashes. He said that the Wabash valley would grow pumpkins as large as a house, that this was a paradise on earth.
STOP NO. 12. GRANVILLE AND ERIE CANAL

The old graveyard you just passed is the Granville graveyard. The town was laid out with a splendid public square, with the idea of making it the county seat of Tippecanoe county but this failed and the county seat went to LaFayette .
When the canal was built through here Granville prospered. In 1873, 74 and 75 I worked on the canal. Like Garfield, I drove a horse. I made three trips along here in 1874 and worked on a dredge, dredging the canal. In 1875 I again drove a horse on the canal from Riverside to LaFayette . Here is the best view of the old canal bed that you can get from any place. The canal was filled with water high enough to run a boat and the horse came up the north side, on the tow path. When the boats passed one boat would pull over to the side and drop the rope and the other boat would run over the rope. There was about seven feet of water in the canal.

Across the river are the Indian hills. If you haven't read Sanford Cox's Old Settlers, you should. He describes those hills. He went up there at sunset. He also describes his fight with wild hogs, and a wild boar. There at the end of the Indian hills is a creek, which is known as Indian creek, but it was formerly known as Rivier de Bois Rouge—river of the Redwood. It was marked on a map of the United States by an early geographer, who knew this valley as far back as 1777. You are standing in the presence of a well known stream. The English were the greatest explorers on earth and they knew this valley.

We ought not to get away from one thing, that is the treaty of 1783, which brought more credit to American statesmanship than any treaty ever made, because in that treaty they described the northwest corner of the Lake of the Woods as the northwest corner of the United States , and when you go home get a map and see how much of that territory runs up into Canada , and see how much we have lost by the weakness of American statesmen.
STOP NO. 13. FORT OUIATENON

(Inscription on stone):
1719 FORT OUIATENON STOOD 200 FT. SOUTH OF THIS SPOT. ERECTED BY GEN. DE LAFAYETTE CHAPTER D. A. R. 1907

About $40,000 worth of fur was handled in that fort in a year. The old town of Cincinnatis was on the raise just north. It flourished for a little while and then disappeared. The town of LaGrange was about 4 miles down the river. This was the fort (pointing to it). It was owned by the English in 1765 but later fell into the hands of the French Canadians. The Fort was on top of the hill just 200 feet south of this monument.

These Indian settlements reached from up above LaFayette down to the Kickapoo country, and on the other side of the river from Wea creek down to Shawnee, and when the white men came it was one of the largest Indian settlements in the United States .
The Miami corn that was raised in this valley was said to be the best grade of Indian corn raised in this country. It was a white flint corn. No one knows just how long the Indians lived here.
STOP NO. 14. FULTON ISLANDS AND BLACK ROCK

This was the head of navigation of the flat boats. The flat boats were made just beyond the islands. Across the river is Flint Creek and the Flint bar is just below. The flat boats were made at the Flint bar. Wooden troughs were run from here down to the river and the grain was hauled here and dumped into the troughs and the boats loaded. That was when Fulton , Marvin and Brown were operating here. That is about all I know of the Black Rock or the use the white man put it to. They dumped their grain into the troughs and loaded the boats from this side of the river and hauled it to New Orleans . The old town of LaGrange was built just above Black Rock, about a mile in Shelby township, Tippecanoe county . The elevator at West Point is almost in line with High Gap from here. All the grain in Tippecanoe county and Warren county until 1846 was loaded at Black Rock and the Flint bar. There was a grain elevator on the river at the bar.
STOP NO. 15

Just west of the crossing of the Independence road and the C. A. & S. Railroad, on the north side of the wagon road,
was fought the battle of Kickapoo, June 1, 1791. It is certain that six Indians were killed and 52 Kickapoo Indians taken prisoner. Just west of where this battle was fought, across the road from the Milligan farm, was the old town of Warrenton, the first county seat of Warren county , and where the first county court was held in Warren county , in the home of Enoch Farmer. About a quarter of a mile up the road is Kickapoo Falls and near these falls in 1822 the Kickapoo and Pottawattomie Indians lost a pitched battle and about 80 Indians or 40 on either side were killed.

div.head: General Charles Scott and His March To Ouiatenon
div.byline: By J. W. WHICKCAR, Attica, Ind.
div.p: The state of Virginia financed George Rogers Clark and his little volunteer army was a part of the state militia of Virginia , on which account the state of Virginia claimed and actually took possession of all of the northwest territory. This territory was first governed by the laws of Virginia and her institutions were established here. When Virginia beheld from the sunset side of her western mountains the northwestern territory and sent her militia to do battle for its possession, she claimed it beyond the rivers that skirted her western boundaries to the Father of Waters, from the northwest comer of the Lake of the Woods to the mouth of the Ohio . Out of this territory has been carved six of the great north central states, and these six states now stand as enduring and lofty monuments to the magnanimity and princely liberality and devotion of Virginia to the general government.

"Since God gave the fruitful land of Canaan to Moses and Israel, such a gift of present and future empire has never been made to any people", as this territory which made these sovereign states, drained by the Mississippi river and its eastern tributaries, an empire of present and future wealth, capable of supplying all the needs of the restless, ceaseless current of humanity in these great and growing states.

It was Virginia 's title to the northwestern territory that England acknowledged in the treaty of 1783. Previous to this, in the various treaties of the white people, at the conclusion of other wars in which the native Red man took no part and had no interest, this territory was bartered and traded as a pawn, to be used in driving a good bargain at the conclusion of war, the title passing as part of the terms of the various treaties. With the Red man of the forest this land was not a thing to pawn and barter, to him it was a sacred thing, a gift of the great Manitou to the Indian, a perpetual benediction
of love from the source of his being. Here was established the family from which he sprang, and here were the graves of his fathers and his loved ones; here he had loved, and wooed and mated, and here his children were born; here he had quenched his thirst from bubbling springs, and lived beneath the spreading branches of boundless forests, or gone to the chase for furs and raiment, food and tents for shelter. He pitched his tent beneath the twining vines, where his children could play and his squaw could care for the family, protected by its shelter from the rays of the summer sun, the rain and the storm. He too had his religion and his faith in a neverending summer land of the soul, he hoped for sparkling streams and rivers and the fadeless verdure of an eternal forest, "The Happy Hunting Ground", where sorrow never entered, misfortune, sickness and death never came. His hope and faith in his religion was as fixed and unfaltering as any of the bravest disciples that ever died for the cause of the Cross. He sang his death song under slow tortures, recounted his deeds of merit and proclaimed his hope and faith in eternal happiness beyond his earthly trials, and anticipated a blissful reward hereafter with all the calmness and confidence of a Christian philosopher.

The Indian who inhabited this country at no time recognized the title of ownership of it in any government of the white race. They denied the claims of titles made by France, by England , by the state of Virginia and by the United States . They claimed this northwest territory as their own, and along the valley of the Wabash , from the mouth of the Tippecanoe river to where the waters of the Vermilion mingled with the Wabash , all of this valley, from the Tippecanoe to the Vermilion, was "Ouiatenon". But with this the Red man was not content, and, as other races, he visioned happiness beneath an arched canopy of blue, set with different stars, and wandered far away in search of the fulfilment of this hope. They always returned to Ouiatenon.

On the 1st day of April, 1791, Antoine Gamelin, an intelligent French merchant, was sent up the Wabash from Vincennes by Major John Hamtramck, then commandant under St. Clair at Vincennes , for the purpose of making a sincere
and honest offer to bring about peace with the Indians in the upper Wabash country. Gamelin stopped in the Piankeshaw village on the Vermilion river near where it empties into the Wabash and the Kickapoo village in the same neighborhood, and from there he visited the Kickapoos on Kickapoo creek, and Pine creek across the river from Attica, and on the 14th of April, 1791, held a council with the Wea and Kickapoo Indians at Ouiatenon. Here he found everything hostile. As a Frenchman he was welcomed, but was plainly told that it was useless to ask them (the Indians) to restrain their young men, for they were "being constantly encouraged by the British", and one of the chiefs said to him, "Know ye, that the village of Ouiatenon is the sepulchre of all our ancestors".

Marauding bands of all the tribes in and about the territory of Ouiatenon journeyed far to the east, and far to the south, in search of spoils, and adventure, and to attack the scattered settlements of the white man then coming into the frontier forests. It was these attacks of the marauding bands that justified General Charles Scott and his seven hundred and fifty Kentucky soldiers in their march to Ouiatenon in the spring of 1791.

The Indians felt secure in the land of Ouiatenon. The French had been in this country as early as 1688, and the English had a trading post called Ouiatenon as early as 1718. The English colonel, George Groghan, who was in charge of the Indian department for the British government, visited the Ouiatenon territory and stopped at the trading post in 1765, and at that time found fourteen French families living there at the fort. At this time the Ouiatenon country was the most densely populated by the Indians of any in the United States , and it has been estimated that there were 15,000 Indians living in that territory.

A letter to Thomas Jefferson, dated August 7, 1785, gives an account of a council of many of the Algonquin tribes at Ouiatenon. Charles A. Goodrich says, in his history, that
between the years 1783 and 1790, not less than 1500 inhabitants of Kentucky , or emigrants to that country, and probably double that number, had been massacred by the Indians, and that repeated efforts had been made by the government to obtain peace, notwithstanding which
the butcheries of the savages still continued in their most appaling forms.

Another historian estimates that during this same period 2,000 children were carried captive from Kentucky by the Indians, and Elmore Barce says that 15,000 horses were stolen from the Kentuckians by the Indians during this period. Many of the marauding Indians in Kentucky , who took part in the killing of the citizens and carrying away the children and the horses, were from Ouiatenon, and when these Kentuckians enlisted under General Scott in 1791 to march to Ouiatenon, they were a determined body of men, bent on revenge for the depredations the Indians of this locality had made in their marauding warfare in Kentucky . Many of them had lost their children or their parents, killed by the Indians, and nearly all of them had lost horses, stolen by the Indians of the Ouiatenon country. The government, owing to the pressing demands of the western people, had authorized the establishment of a local board of war for the district of Kentucky . This board was composed of Brigadier General Charles Scott, leader of the Kentucky militia, Harry Innes, John Brown, Benjamin Logan and Isaac Shelby , and they were vested with discretionary powers for the defense of the settlement, and the prosecution of the war. The government had now fully determined on a definite plan of action.

On the 2nd of January, 1791, between sunset and daylight, the Indians surprised the new settlement on the Muskingum, called the Big Bottom, forty miles above Marietta, killing eleven men, one woman and two children, and General Rufus Putnam wrote to President Washington on the 8th of the same month saying that the little garrison at Fort Harmar, consisting of a little over twenty men, could afford no protection to the settlements, that the whole number of efficient men in the Muskingum country would not exceed 287 and that many of them were badly armed, and that unless the government speedily sent a body of troops for their protection they were a ruined people. Virginia , Pennsylvania and Kentucky were all being sorely pressed by savage incursions, and Barce says that it was a fortunate circumstance for the future of the
great west that George Washington was then President of the United States .

On the 16th of May, the American prisoner, Thomas Rhea, captured by a party of Delawares and Munsees, arrived at Sandusky. An Indian chieftain was there with 150 warriors, and parties of Indians were coming in daily with prisoners and scalps, and on the 24th of May the alarm came that a large body of American troops, in three columns, was moving towards the Miami towns. The Indians burned their houses and moved to the Maumee, where they were living in clever cabins built by the Pottawattomie and other Indians, and stores of corn, pork and beans and other provisions, together with arms and ammunition, the English were daily issuing to the Indians. The savages were coming in in parties of one, two and three, and as many as four and five hundred at a time, and receiving supplies from the English and the French Canadians, and preparing for an attack on the Americans. The Indians in the Ouiatenon country were allied to the British and were taking part in these arrangements for war, and on the 19th of March, 1791, the secretary of war issued orders to General Charles Scott of Kentucky to lead an expedition against the Wea or Ouiatenon towns on the Wabash . The expedition was not to proceed until the 10th day of May, as hopes were entertained that John Proctor might negotiate a peace. The force to be employed was to consist of 750 mounted volunteers and officers. All the Indians who ceased to resist were to be spared. Women and children and as many warriors as possible were to be taken prisoner, but to be treated with humanity. This expedition was to be led by Charles Scott, brigadier general, then in command of the Kentucky militia.

The 10th day of May arrived, but Proctor was not heard from. The hostilities of the savages were daily increasing. Scott delayed a few days longer in the hope that intelligence might arrive, but on the 23rd day of May, 1791, he crossed the Ohio river at the mouth of the Kentucky river and launched into the wilderness. Before him lay 155 miles of forest, swamp and stream. The rain fell in torrents and every river was beyond its banks. His horses were soon worn out
and his provisions spoiled, but he and his brave army pressed on.

The Kentucky river enters the Ohio very nearly opposite the point where the line divides Jefferson and Switzerland counties in Indiana. Scott's march led through Switzerland, Jefferson, Jennings, Scott, Bartholomew, Shelby, Johnsen, Marion, Hendricks, Boone, Montgomery and Tippecanoe counties, and before he left some of his army had gone through Fountain and into Warren counties. The march was along the head waters of the White river. Scott marched to Ouiatenon twelve years after George Rogers Clark had taken Vincennes , five months before St. Clair's defeat, three years before Wayne fought the battle of Fallen Timbers (Scott was with Wayne in this battle) and twenty years before the battle of Tippecanoe . Without bearings, without compass, guided by the North star, he entered a forest that had never been penetrated before by the Americans. Soon his provisions failed. His horses tired but he marched on, fording the flooded creeks and bottom lands, wet from the cold spring rains, he and his Kentuckians marched through the unbroken forests. His march was practically a straight line. The army found game, deer and water fowl, and parched corn and dried venison sufficient for their food.

At eleven o'clock on the morning of the first day of June, 1791, they stopped for dinner on a beautiful stretch of prairie. Dinner over, before twelve o'clock they were mounted and moving on. Scott was in the Shawnee prairie, south and east of the Wea Plains, when his army saw a lone Indian horseman to the right, northwest of them. They tried to intercept him, but the Indian had a good mount, knew the country and rode away.

Barce says:
On the morning of June 1st, 1791, the landscape of the Wea was a thing of beauty. To the north lies the long range of Indian hills, crowned with vast trees and scarped with many sharp ravines. At the south edge of these hills flows the Wabash , winding in and out with graceful curves, and marked in its course by a narrow fringe of woodland. To the east lies Wea Creek, jutting out into the plain with a sharp turn, and then gliding on again to the river. Within this enclosure of wood and stream lie the meadows of the Ouiatenon, dotted here and there with pleasant groves and filled with the aroma of countless blossoms.

When General Scott and his 750 mounted men rode through the gap in the high land and timber, and paused at the foot of the Round Top Hills, and looked across the meadows of the Wea Plains, lying gently and peacefully between them and the Wabash river, he or one of his soldiers, raised his rifle and shot at the lone Miami chieftan as he rode off in the direction of Ouiatenon. The Indian Hills echoed back across the peaceful, placid Wabash the reverberating sound of the tocsin of war. This army bore the beacon light of a new government through the wilderness to the frontier, to blaze the way for civilization. The sound of this rifle resounded along the Wabash down to Black Rock, past whose cliffs and bluffs the river coursed its winding way, and the men on horseback from the south, the American cavaliers, beheld the
beautiful, fertile valley of the Wabash . This valley had been the home and hunting ground of the Red man of the woods, wild in his habits, satisfied with his mode of living, finding his food, his raiment and his shelter in the woods bordering the river and the prairies beyond, and now for the first time the cavalier had reached the Red man's home, his stronghold, had reached Ouiatenon.

Scott stopped only long enough at the foot of the Rouna Top Hills for the shot to be fired in the direction of the lone horseman, and to give his orders to his officers. He and Col. James Wilkinson rode after the horseman, toward Ouiatenon, northwest three miles, on the river bank. Colonel John Harden, with his sixty mounted infantry, and a troop of light horses under Captain McCoy, rode to the left where off to the distance of two miles they could see a small village and four miles further on, was another village. These villages were temporary only, established by a few Kickapoo warriors who had come across the river to hunt with the Miami. The Miami chieftain rode to Ouiatenon and alarmed his tribes. The Kickapoos had no knowledge of the approach of the army until Colonel Harden and his mounted men were within a mile of their village. These Indians mounted their horses and rode for the Kickapoo ford. This ford was eight miles distant down the river, the only ford with a rock bottom between the Tippecanoe river and the Vermilion, the best and safest ford, the only place, on account of the river being up, where the river could then be forded. Harden's men followed close onto the Kickapoos. The Kickapoos rode straight for the ford and across the river, Harden's men following, and in Warren county , about two miles north of the mouth of Pine creek, Harden fought the Battle of Kickapoo. Here he knew he had killed six warriors and captured a few women and children, and as he returned he picked up those that were left behind, and at six o'clock in the evening, when he joined Scott and Wilkinson, he reported having killed six warriors and taken fifty-two prisoners. Upon the approach of Scott and Wilkinson to Ouiatenon, a small Indian camp in the bottom lands of the Wabash river, near the mouth of Wea creek, these Indians got into their canoes and crossed the Wabash . A
brief skirmish ensued, during which several Indian warriors were killed and two Americans wounded.

Scott's victory was complete. His men had committed no depredations, they had taken no scalps, they had acquitted themselves with credit, and proved their bravery. A large quantity of corn, a variety of household goods, peltry and other articles were burned with the Ouiatenon village, which consisted at that time of about seventy houses, many of them well furnished. Scott lamented that the condition of his troops prevented him from sweeping on to the head of the Wabash . He said he had the kind of men to do it, but he lacked fresh horses and provisions, and was forced to return to Kentucky .

On the 4th of June he released sixteen of the weakest and most infirm of his prisoners and gave them a written address of peace to the Wabash tribes. This address was written in a firm, manly tone, and on the same day, the 4th day of June, he destroyed the villages about Ouiatenon and the growing corn and gardens, and started on his return trip to Kentucky . This grand old Revolutionary soldier had done well, (he was yet to fight with Wayne at the battle of the Fallen Timbers) and with only five wounded, and without the loss of a single man, and without a discreditable deed committed by one of his troops, he had killed thirty-two warriors and taken fifty-eight prisoners. Forty-one of these prisoners he delivered to Captain Joseph Ashton of the First United States regiment, at Fort Steuben (Clarksville), and thus finished the first march of an American army into the northwest territory, to there float the American Flag and establish the government of the United States of America.

Scott was born in 1733, in Cumberland county , Virginia . He was a private with Braddock and Washington at Braddock's defeat in 1755. He raised the first regiment of men that was raised for the war of the Revolution south of the James River. He was a colonel at the Battle of Trenton, and was made a lieutenant general in 1777. He was sent to reinforce Maxwell in New Jersey and was with mad Anthony Wayne at Stoney Point in 1779. He was present and heard Washington's instructions to General Charles Lee, and afterwards was a witness at Lee's trial. He took part in the battle
of Monmouth and was taken prisoner at Charlottesville . He marched from the mouth of the Kentucky river to Ouiatenon and fought the battles along the Wabash June 1, 1791, and later was with mad Anthony Wayne at the battle of Fallen Timbers. He was governor of Kentucky from 1808 to 1812, and died, highly honored, at the age of 80 years, in 1813. Such was the character and reputation of the man who led this army in 1791.

div.head: Zachariah Cicot
div.p: As the English Army, under command of Cornwallis, marched captive between the lines of the American soldiers on one side and French soldiers on the other side, at Yorktown, Virginia , October 19, 1781, there was born near the Big springs in the town of Independence, Warren county , Indiana, a child. The father of this child was a French Canadian, a trapper and fur dealer at Post Ouiatenon. His name was Cicot. The mother of this child was a full-blood Pottawattomie Indian, the daughter and only child of a respected chief of the tribe. The child was christened Zachariah, Zachariah Cicot. After his marriage to the Indian maiden the elder Cicot chose to live with the tribe of his wife and her father. The birth of the child was welcome news in the Indian camp, for some day he would be the chief of the tribe. The elder Cicot was adopted into the tribe. He hunted and fished with the Indians and accepted their habits and dress. He loved his wife and her people and was proud of his first-born child. He was happy and content with his life on the Wabash and the red men of the forest. The child grew apace with the red children of the tribe, and as he grew into boyhood he became an expert with the bow and arrow, and with his father's rifle he was the best marksman in the tribe. He was at home in the waters of the Wabash river and could paddle a boat, could swim and dive like a fish or water fowl, and he liked the water. He grew very fast with almost perfect form, and with the natural and wild life of the river and the woods, he was fully developed at the age of 16.

In the spring of 1793 his father took him to old Vincennes and placed him in the care of the priest to be tutored in the ways, arts, and religion of his father's people. He was studious and soon learned to read and write. In three years he had mastered all the branches taught in the schools at Vincennes ,
and during those three years he had taken several journeys south to New Orleans with the priest and became acquainted with the Seminoles, Creeks, Chickasaws, and Chocktaws of the south and the French in New Orleans . They were three eventful years, a great and beneficial experience in his life. In the spring of 1797 he returned to his parents and the Indian tribe at Independence. The next year, 1798, his father died leaving five children, Zachariah the eldest. Without complaint he assisted his mother in rearing the four younger children. In the year 1800 he began raising horses. He was then 19 years of age. He soon had a small herd of good riding horses and some cattle and started on his career as an Indian trader, trading horses for furs and converting the furs into cash, and by this means, Zachariah Cicot mounted the Pottawattomie and the Kickapoo tribes. The Miami was a better warrior than either of these tribes, but he was a man of the woods and did not take to the horse. This was his undoing and for the reason that they were mounted, the Pottawattomie and the Kickapoo (though they were inferior in every way to the Miami) were able to, and did encroach upon their hunting grounds. For six years he continued his vocation as a trader undisturbed.

In the autumn of 1807, Tecumseh and the Prophet with a few Shawnee warriors, held a conference beneath the spreading branches of a magnificent oak (ever after known as the Council Oak), which stood within the corporation limits of Attica, (this tree was cut down in 1866). In this council it was agreed that the Shawnees could locate at the mouth of the Tippecanoe river and have a hunting ground of their own over the territory drained by Shawnee creek and north to the Wabash river, and east to the mouth of the Tippecanoe , then up the Tippecanoe . All the land south of the Wabash river was Miami territory, and all that part of the hunting ground granted near Cicot's trading post was Miami territory.

Zacariah Cicot attended this council, listened to all the discussions and took an active and earnest part in them. He knew Tecumseh and the Prophet and did not like either of them, and he did not like the Shawnees and was bitterly opposed to letting them have grounds upon which they might
hunt. He was opposed to their coming to this territory. He believed Tecumseh to be nothing more than a hired representative of the British and a trouble-maker, and he had no better opinion of the Prophet, whom he considered a religious fanatic. He frankly told the Indians in the convention his opinion of them. He did not want the Shawnees across the Wabash from his trading post. He was not fond of the Miamis, but he much preferred them to the Shawnees.

His grandfather was yet living and chief of his tribe, and his grandfather thought the three years at Vincennes and his knowledge of the white man's learning had been the undoing of Cicot, before this meeting, and now he knew it. The old chief favored the coming of Tecumseh and the Prophet and the Shawnees and his tribe, and all his family sympathized with the chief. While Cicot was alone in his immediate tribe, there were among the Pottawattomie, Kickapoos, Miamis, and Delawares some who believed as Cicot believed and said so, but they were a hopeless minority.

The great chief and sachem of the Pottawattomie, Aniquiba, was the father of Topenebee and his sister Kaukeema. After the death of Aniquiba for nearly half a century, Topenebee was principal chief and sachem of all the tribes of the Pottawattomie. Kaukeema had married a French trader by the name of William Burnett, and by him had raised a large family of children, and they were all anxious to join and become a part of Tecumseh's confederacy. In accordance with the long fixed custom of the Pottawattomies, Zachariah Cicot would, at the death of his mother's father, become the chief of his tribe; but he was so determined in his objections to the Shawnees and so pronounced in his denunciation of Tecumseh and the Prophet and their scheme of confederation, that after the conclusion of the conference beneath the spreading branches of the Council Oak in Attica, his mother's father passed the chieftainship over his head and announced that the younger brother, George Cicot, would become chief at his death. At the conclusion of the council, in the presence of the chiefs of all the tribes, with great ceremony George Cicot was declared the successor of his mother's father as chief of the tribe. Soon after this treaty the old chief died,
and George Cicot became a chief of the tribe of the Pottawattomie, and with equal ceremony, Zachariah Cicot, at this council was banished from all the tribes in the Wabash valley; denounced as a white dog; a traitor to the redmen; and a coward. Zachariah Cicot spent that winter in Independence with his mother. His life was in danger, and in the spring of 1808 he went south and spent a year or more with the various tribes of southern Indians. He warned them against Tecumseh and the Prophet and the danger of becoming a party to the Shawnee confederation. He was now 27 years of age, possessing the grace and bearing of an Indian with the suave and artistic demeanor of a French gentleman. He stood full six feet in height; weighed one hundred and ninety pounds; had dark swarthy complexion; keen black eyes; was quick and wiry and very strong for his weight; skilled in the hunt; enduring in the chase; acquainted with the stealth of the redman's woodcraft; brave and possessed of an iron constitution. Tecumseh viewed him as a dangerous enemy; and Governor Harrison considered him a true American, a faithful friend, and a valuable scout, and soon learned of his actions and attitude at the Indian council held at Attica. Governor Harrison knew Zachariah Cicot and he was his most trusted friend, scout, and sharp-shooter on the upper Wabash frontier. He possessed the keen insight of his French father to drive a good bargain, and the stealth and endurance of his Indian ancestors in the chase or on the march, and doubtless the governor knew something of his purpose in his journey south to spend some time among the various Indian tribes in the early spring of 1808.

In the month of June, of this year 1808, Tecumseh and the Prophet and about forty Shawnees established themselves at the mouth of the Tippecanoe river. It is interesting now that a few weeks before the Shawnees came to their alloted hunting grounds, Zachariah Cicot, their out-spoken enemy, who at that time was acquainted with more Indians, knew the purposes of the French, English, and American traders, still lingering along the Wabash , better than any one person in the Northwestern territory, should leave his family, his friends, and the haunts of his youth to spend a year or more
among the southern Indian tribes. He had a purpose in this journey. It was the psychological time to inform the Indian tribes of the south of the aims and purposes of Tecumseh and the Prophet, apprise them of their true character, and warn them of the danger of allying themselves with the Shawnee confederacy. No one was so well qualified as he for this mission. He had attended the council of 1807 and in that council he had told Tecumseh, the Prophet, and the Shawnees to their teeth that the Prophet was a shrewd deceiver and religious fanatic and nothing more, that Tecumseh himself was a paid hireling of the British, that the Shawnee confederacy was nothing new, that it had been the slogan of King Phillip, of Pontiac, and Red Jacket and was now presented to them as something new that had originated with Tecumseh and the Prophet; that the fair fabric of this dream had been presented to the Shawnees by the British; that the conversion and inspiration of the Shawness to this cause had its source in British gold. He had but recently had the epaulets cut from his shoulders and the ermine of a chief and the blessing of his grandfather taken from him and given to his brother. Small honors they may have been, but the events of the council of 1807 cut deep, and he determined that he would repay. It was his visit to the southern Indian tribes in 1808 and 9 that prepared Pushmataha, the loyal Choctaw chief, for Tecumseh's visit in 1811, and forestalled his plans for a confederation of all the Indians in one concerted effort to stop the whiteman's encroachment. He had impressed Pushmataha with the true character of Tecumseh and the real aims of the Shawnee confederation. In the early spring of 1810 Cicot returned to his home at Independence, stopping with Governor Harrison at Vincennes for a few weeks on his way home and continued trading horses for furs. He was now the only man upon whom Governor Harrison could depend, living along the Wabash north of the Ten o'clock line. In the late spring of 1810 he took his furs to Detroit , and he went back to Detroit again in the autumn. He, perhaps, was more fitted than any other man to get the information desired by Governor Harrison as to the activities of the British and Indians. On his return he went to Vincennes to consult with the governor.

With the approaching summer of 1811 Cicot began making preparations to leave the Indian camp at Independence, and whenever Governor Harrison called, join him at Vincennes . He arranged with some friendly Indians, in the south part of Warren county , to take care of forty head of his horses. He arranged to take his furs to the mouth of the Big Vermilion river to be taken, on a flatboat by a French-Canadian of his acquaintance, to New Orleans . When he left Independence, he knew that what property he could not take in his boat would be destroyed or appropriated by the Indians for their own use. Thus he was prepared, waiting and ready to go. When in the summer of 1811 he received a note from Governor Harrison directing him to come immediately, prepared to act as a scout for the army which would soon prepare to march against the Indians at the mouth of the Tippecanoe , Cicot had noticed that the Indians of Warren county were in a state of great excitement. He soon became aware that some great disturbance was on foot, as the Indians were holding war and scalp dances and were arming themselves. They were ornamenting their persons with red and black paint and other horrid paraphernalia of savage warfare.

The note was no sooner received than Cicot began making hurried preparations for his departure. He secretly packed everything of value that he could take in his progress, and, unknown to the Indians left Independence at night, pulling rapidly down the Wabash .

It was on the 26th of September, 1811, that Governor Harrison with an army of about nine hundred men left Vincennes on his expedition against the Indians in the upper Wabash valley. Captain Touissant Dubois was in command of the scouts, whose duty it was to guide the army to the Prophet's town at the mouth of the Tippecanoe . Dubois and his trusted guard relied on Zachariah Cicot to determine the route the army should take from Vincennes to the Prophet's town. Zachariah Cicot was now 30 years of age. He had lived all his life along the Wabash river and most of it at what is now Independence, Warren county , Indiana. He knew the upper Wabash country; he knew the forest; he knew the Wabash river and its tributaries; he knew the Indians and their habits and methods of warfare; and Harrison and
Dubois considered him and his knowledge of the country in which they were going to be a valuable addition to their army. He had lived all his life with the Indians on the upper Wabash . He had raised the horses, and mounted on horse back the Pottawattomie and the Kickapoo. His mother and all his family were Indians. The French priest, during the three years he was with them, had instilled in him a bitter dislike for the English and a love for the United States of America, and his love for his government was stronger than his family ties or tribal relations. It was not that he loved the Indians less, but he loved the United States more. That tells the story of Zachariah Cicot, Harrison's most trusted scout. He was ready and willing to sacrifice all he possessed, even to his life, for his country. The time had come; the die was cast; and he was now soon going to meet on the field of battle the chieftains who had banished him from his people and his tribe. He was glad of the opportunity to serve his country and battle for its cause.

From Fort Harrison, near Terre Haute , the army came up the river on the east bank to the south edge of Montezuma in Parke county , here they crossed the Wabash . It took them two hours to cross the river here. From this place, in Vermilion county , Indiana, they marched near the west bank of the Wabash to a point near the mouth of Coal creek a little below the south line of Fountain county near Cayuga. Here on the west bank of the river they built a small fort as a base of supplies and sent forty men back to Ft. Harrison to take care of the women, children, and supplies there. Eight men were left to guard the fort. From this point Cicot guided them west and north. They crosses the Vermillion river near where the upper bridge at Eugene now spans this stream. From there they went nearly direct to or near State Line City, where they entered Warren county . From there they went to the Round Grove near Hedrick or Sloan, where they camped. The first night out from there they marched to the Army Ford where they crossed Pine creek, always continuing in the open prairie, and about ten miles west of the Wabash river and from the Army Ford through open prairie to the battle ground, and away from the possibility of surprise or ambush by the enemy.

He took an active part in the battle of Tippecanoe , with bravery and valor worthy of the soldier that he was. After the battle he returned to Vincennes with the army, and again as a scout in 1812 he came up the east bank of the Wabash river with General Samuel Hopkins. He remained in Vincennes until the spring of 1815, found his horses and their increase safe with his trusted Indian friends in the hills of Possum Run, north of Covington in Warren county , and again at Independence resumed his trade with the Indians. The cause for which he had fought having won, he was respected more than ever by his dusky Indian friends.

In the spring of 1816 he returned to Vincennes and had prepared a large, hewed log house. The logs were numbered and like the stone for King Solomon's temple fit exactly as they were set in place. This log cabin he rafted up the Wabash , and erected it in the early spring of 1817. It was the first house north of the ten o'clock line in Indiana.

On the 2nd day of October, 1818, he married Elizabeth, the daughter of Perig, a Pottawattomie chief, and to this union three children were born. One son, John Baptist Cicot, and two daughters, Emily and Sophia. On account of Zachariah Cicot having been banished by the Indians, his active part in the War of 1812, his loyalty to the United States government, he took part in all county, state and national affairs as a citizen of the United States . The United States government alloted to Z. Cicot and his children about three thousand acres of land in Adams township, Carroll county , Indiana, fronting on the Wabash river for about two miles. This is known as Cicot's reservation and the village of Lockport is situated in about the center of this reservation. This in addition to the Independence reservation of 640 acres granted to Perig, who gave it to the son of Cicot, who sold or traded it to Zachariah. There is a lake in Jefferson township, Cass county , Indiana, named Lake Cicot for Z. Cicot and a street in Logansport called Cicot street for him. His two daughters were given a half section each and his son received one section from Perig, his grandfather. Zachariah Cicot bought this section or the right to locate it from his son and laid it at Independence, including his house and the Big spring. On this section known as Cicot's reserve he laid out the town of
Independence in 1832. His log cabin stood until about 25 years ago when it was torn down and used on the highways for bridge timber. Emily, his oldest daughter, received a good education, was a respected and intelligent woman, and was government interpreter at some of the Indian treaties as shown in the government archives at Washington, D. C. In the Indian treaty, January 21, 1832, Zachariah Cicot received $950. In the treaty at Chicago , September 21, 1833, he received $1,800. This was his last allowance as an Indian trader. At this time he was considered a wealthy man. In 1832 he suffered a light paralytic stroke from which he recovered. While Isaac Naylor was judge of the Warren circuit court, he and Zachariah Cicot and several others who had been in the Battle of Tippecanoe went over the route or trail of the army and identified its camping places and related many interesting anecdotes of the march. Much of the route of the army lay along an old Indian trail, which was afterwards travelled considerably as a highway.

After a life of toil and struggle, in the year 1850, Zachariah Cicot died very near where he was born, and he had not received even a slight recognition of his valuable services. His burial place is known but no monument begs memory of him. He lies by the side of his wife in the old grave-yard at Independence. His wife's grave is marked.

He was a noble-hearted, zealous and patriotic hero. His achievements may never be fully appreciated, and his glory may go unsung, yet it is to be hoped that this patriotic soldier of the Wabash valley may be given the glory and the honor and the place beside his comrades-in-arms, in the history and conquest of the northwest, and the Wabash valley that is so justly his, and his name and memory should be linked with the other noble and heroic souls whose labors were united on that victorious march and crowned with success in the Battle of Tippecanoe . Like a golden chain linking the past to the present in the rosary of years, is the record of the pioneer, the glory of whose labors rests like a benediction on every hill and stream along the Wabash valley and whose names like incense are redolent with deeds of bravery, chivalry, and valor.
